definition:
A ring $R$ is called **left/right perfect** if for any left/right
$R$-module $M$ there exists a projective cover $p:P\to M$.

A ring $R$ is called **left/right semiperfect** if for any left/right
finitely-generated $R$-module $M$ there exists a projective cover
$p:P\to M$.

It can be shown that there are rings which are left perfect, but not
right perfect. However being semiperfect is left-right symmetric
property.

Some examples of semiperfect rings include:

1.  perfect rings;

2.  left/right Artinian rings;

3.  finite-dimensional algebras over a field $k$.
